user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_upgraded_connection_mark_app_closed_:
```c
void
MHD_upgraded_connection_mark_app_closed_ (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  /* Cache 'daemon' here to avoid data races */
  struct MHD_Daemon *const daemon = connection->daemon;
#if defined(MHD_USE_THREADS)
  mhd_assert (NULL == daemon->worker_pool);
#endif /* MHD_USE_THREADS */
  mhd_assert (NULL != connection->urh);
  mhd_assert (0 != (daemon->options & MHD_TEST_ALLOW_SUSPEND_RESUME));

  MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ (&daemon->cleanup_connection_mutex);
  connection->urh->was_closed = true;
  connection->resuming = true;
  daemon->resuming = true;
  MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (&daemon->cleanup_connection_mutex);
  if ( (MHD_ITC_IS_VALID_ (daemon->itc)) &&
       (! MHD_itc_activate_ (daemon->itc, "r")) )
  {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    MHD_DLOG (daemon,
              _ ("Failed to signal resume via " \
                 "inter-thread communication channel.\n"));
#endif
  }
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
#if defined(MHD_USE_THREADS)
  mhd_assert (NULL == daemon->worker_pool);
#endif /* MHD_USE_THREADS */
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The mhd_assert call is inside a conditional compilation block (#if defined(MHD_USE_THREADS)). This code is not inherently unreachable: when MHD_USE_THREADS is defined the call is compiled and can be executed, and when it is not defined the preprocessor removes the code (so it is not present in the translation unit). There is no construct here that makes the code unconditionally unreachable at run time (unlike e.g. an if (0) block or code after a return).
